firstChapter.htmlHeader: Obstructive sleep apnoea syndrome: Summary
firstChapter.htmlStringContent:
• Obstructive sleep apnoea/hypopnoea syndrome (OSAHS) is the coexistence of excessive daytime sleepiness with irregular breathing at night.
    • The British Thoracic Society (BTS) uses the term 'obstructive sleep apnoea syndrome' (OSAS) for people with repetitive apnoeas and symptoms of sleep fragmentation with excessive daytime sleepiness. This CKS topic will use the BTS term of obstructive sleep apnoea syndrome (OSAS) when referring to OSAHS.
  • OSAS affects all age groups, with the highest incidence between 30 and 60 years of age.
  • OSAS should be suspected in a person who reports any of the following symptoms:
    • Excessive daytime sleepiness and snoring and/or impaired concentration.
    • Witnessed apnoeas or choking noises while sleeping.
    • Feeling unrefreshed on waking.
    • Mood swings, personality changes, or depression.
    • Nocturia.
  • OSAS should be suspected in children with snoring and pauses in breathing, which may be followed by a gasp or snort. Parents may also report:
    • Restlessness and sudden arousals from sleep, laboured breathing, unusual sleep posture (for example head bent backwards), and bedwetting.
    • Daytime symptoms such as changes in behaviour, irritability, poor concentration, decreased performance at school, tiredness and sleepiness, failure to gain weight or grow, and mouth breathing.
  • To support a diagnosis of OSAS:
    • Daytime sleepiness should be differentiated from other causes of tiredness and fatigue.
    • The person should be asked about their smoking history, family history of OSAS, weight gain, and alcohol or sedative use.
    • The person should be examined for enlarged tonsils, small lower jaw, and nasal blockage.
    • Blood pressure, body mass index, and neck circumference should be recorded.
  • Assessment of a person with suspected OSAS includes:
    • Asking about the effects of daytime sleepiness on driving and employment, relationships, mood, sleeping, and social life.
    • Assessing the severity of sleepiness using an Epworth sleepiness questionnaire.
    • Asking any partner about the person's snoring habits, apnoeas, and choking episodes.
    • Assessing for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), respiratory failure, or cor pulmonale, which may influence the urgency of referral.
    • Arranging investigations if an underlying cause is suspected (for example thyroid function tests if hypothyroidism is suspected).
  • If OSAS is suspected, adults should be referred to a sleep centre for diagnosis and treatment.
  • Urgent referral should be considered for people:
    • With features suggestive of a head and neck cancer.
    • Who have symptoms of daytime sleepiness whilst driving or working with machinery, or are employed in hazardous occupations (for example bus or lorry drivers).
    • With signs of respiratory or heart failure.
    • With symptoms suggestive of severe OSAS and coexistent COPD.
  • For adults where there are concerns about job security, ensure through personal communication with the sleep unit that diagnosis and treatment can be completed within four weeks of referral.
  • Children should be referred to a paediatric ear, nose, and throat specialist if they have adenotonsillar hypertrophy and symptoms of persistent snoring.
  • Management of confirmed OSAS in primary care involves:
    • Advising on weight loss, exercise, smoking cessation, and reducing alcohol intake, if appropriate.
    • Advising the person to try sleeping on their side.
    • Assessing the person's risk for cardiovascular disease and diabetes.
    • Monitoring blood pressure.
    • Giving advice on driving (for example not driving if sleepy, informing the DVLA about their condition, and checking entitlement to drive).
    • Giving advice on support groups (for example www.sleep-apnoea-trust.org).
